line_1: He thinks her ugly as the devil.
line_2: And, though her fops are wond'rous civil,

line_1: And in that point are madder than the devil:
line_2: Some fly, like pendulums, from good to evil,

line_1: A vilipend tongue is the devil,
line_2: And Maggy — na, na! we'll be civil,

line_1: Whose Tongue can complement you to the Devil.
line_2: These I cou'd bear; but not a Rogue so civil,

line_1: As to wage open war with the devil,
line_2: In a world so abounding with evil,

line_1: I'll give thee — to the devil,
Now ev'n go court the Bishops — or the Devil.
line_2: 'Twas yours, had you been honest, wise, or civil;

line_1: Sould be so very like the Devil.
line_2: In Color, way of life and evil,

line_1: The three good Properties of Mr. Devil,
line_2: Like him's Malicious, Envious, and Uncivil,

line_1: The attribute of God and of the Devil.
line_2: Alike the instrument of good and evil,

line_1: And thus broke out — "My Lord, why, what the Devil?
line_2: "Z—ds! damn the Lock! 'fore Gad, you must be civil!

line_1: And send it packing to the Devil;
The mongrel offspring of a Witch and Devil.
line_2: Prone were his eyes to earth, his mind to evil,

line_1: For mighty watchful is the Devil."
line_2: Well; guard us all, I say, from evil!
